reasoning: This targets a central pivot in the paper: whether to rely on broad post-AGI ethical/motivational convergence versus prioritising pluralistic governance, compromise, and threat-prevention. A decisive estimate of P(WAM | reasonably good conditions) would substantially shift strategy (high cruciality) and is directly anchored to the paper’s WAM-convergence framing and section 2.4 argument (high paper-specificity, though convergence-probability questions also arise in adjacent work). However, it is only moderately tractable: ‘reasonably good conditions’, ‘accurate’, and especially ‘motivational’ convergence are difficult to operationalise, and empirical deliberation studies plus formal models would at best provide weak, proxy-based updates rather than anything like a robust probability estimate. The question is mostly clear but inherits non-trivial ambiguity from the paper’s own vagueness about conditions and what counts as sufficient accuracy/motivation. It has an explicit decision flip (very strong decision hook) and minimal extraneous framing (low dead weight). Overall: a strong, decision-relevant research question with major methodological/operationalisation limitations.
title: Probability of motivational convergence on the good under ideal conditions
